Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Middleware for Certificate-Based Authentication

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Every time someone uses a phone or computer to connect to an Internet site, software determines whether the connection is safe or being intercepted by attackers. Unfortunately, this software is error-prone, leaving users vulnerable to having their privacy violated or their personal information stolen due to phishing attacks, identity theft, and unauthorized inspection of their encrypted traffic. A number of solutions are being proposed, but the software is fragmented across many platforms and redundantly or incorrectly implemented. The goal of this research is to develop a trust platform that consolidates the decision-making process into a single location to provide a correct, consistent, and usable service for all existing and future applications. The platform is designed to make it easier for researchers to test and deploy alternative methods for detecting trustworthy Internet sites. The research emphasizes usability, so that users are not faced with error messages that are difficult for them to understand or act on.

The project designs and analyzes middleware that consolidates certificate-based authentication in the operating system. It is designed for both Linux and Android, and automatically overrides the broken decision-making process currently found in many existing applications. Developers are no longer required to provide their own certificate validation function when building applications. The platform supports a variety of plugins for certificate authentication, such as dynamic certificate pinning, crowd-sourced notary services, and a curated root store. Policy configuration enables users or organizations to define how responses from multiple plugins are combined to make a final trust decision. Usability studies are focused on all aspects that require user interaction with the system: installing the system, configuring security and privacy preferences, choosing authentication providers, and receiving actionable notifications and warnings. This research benefits national security by addressing numerous weaknesses in the current trust system with new authentication services. The project contributes to the security community by providing an open source platform for easily extending the current trust system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When applications operate over the Internet, they must transfer information securely. Two of the most important security properties that applications implement are authentication and confidentiality. Authentication ensures that an application is talking to the correct service. For example, it ensures that if your web browser connects to Amazon so you can make a purchase, it really is talking to Amazon, or if your laptop connects to Microsoft to download software updates, it really is talking to Microsoft. Confidentiality ensures that applications encrypt their communications so that an attacker cannot eavesdrop on the connection and, for example, steal a person?s credit card information as they make a purchase online.

 The primary portion of our work focuses on a key problem in this area ? ensuring that applications perform authentication and encryption properly. Past research has shown that developers often make mistakes when writing applications, leaving millions of consumers vulnerable when they communicate over the Internet. The root cause of this problem is that writing secure systems is difficult, and many developers don?t have the specialized training needed to do this properly. Thus, our focus has been to develop software that developers can use to make this job easier. Essentially, our software does all the hard work of authentication and encryption, providing a very simple interface that developers can use.

 To address this problem we created two systems. Our initial approach developed a simple, centralized method for authentication, called TrustBase. This software runs within the operating system (e.g. Microsoft WIndows), intercepts all traffic, and ensures that authentication is performed properly. In a sense, TrustBase works like an antivirus system, but instead protects a computer against developer errors.  We subsequently expanded this approach to include all aspects of secure communication between an application and an Internet service. This system, called the Secure Socket API, enables developers to write only 1-10 lines of code to create a secure connection to an Internet Service, rather than the more typical thousands of lines of code. We have released both systems as open source software, meaning it is free for any company to adopt or extend, as well as free for developers to use.

In the larger picture, our work demonstrates how it is possible to extend the operating system of a computer or phone so that it includes important security features. Moving security guarantees away from applications and into the operating system has a number of advantages. Developers have an easier job writing secure software. If security features need to be fixed or upgraded, the updates can be applied in one place and all applications are upgraded simultaneously, rather than waiting for each developer to update their own applications individually. Finally, major operating system vendors, such as Microsoft, Apple, and Google, have greater resources than smaller companies and individual developers, making it easier to ensure that operating system services are implemented correctly ad patched quickly.

A separate thread of our work studied the human aspects of computer security. Ultimately, computer systems are only as secure as the people who use them. The area of usable security seeks to design systems that take into account the knowledge and capabilities of the users of the system in order to help them effectively use security features. Our work in this area primarily studied secure messaging applications such as WhatsApp, with a focus on helping people understand and use the authentication built into these applications. Ultimately, this work helps people who need secure messaging ? for example those who are communicating sensitive information, or living in a country without free speech protections ? ensure that their conversations are not being intercepted by an adversary.

Our national security depends on increasing the number of cybersecurity experts and increasing the participation of underrepresented groups. Our work played a significant role in helping student researchers to be placed in significant cybersecurity positions in academia and industry. One is an assistant professor at a major university, three are at Sandia National Labs, three are at ManTech (a government security systems contractor), two are at Google, one is at Lawrence Livermore National Lab, and another is a PhD student at a major research university. One of our PhD researchers on the project was a female. We also mentored 23 undergraduates who helped contribute to our research, including writing open source software, writing test cases and documentation, running usability studies, and analyzing data. Of these, 14 were co-authors on at least one paper, and 2 were each the first author on a publication at a top security conference that they initiated. Publications from our research received the 2018 Internet Defense Prize First Runner-Up as well as Honorable Mention and Best Paper awards.
